utterances: Mm-hmm.

Saul is with us from Stevens Point in Wisconsin.
Yes.
I'm a fervent advocate of the five-plus-second rule on scientific grounds.
Really?
Yes.
And that is that it gives the chance for microorganisms, and let's not forget viruses, can mutate to a less pathogenic form.
(Soundbite of laughter)
So you want to let evolution have its say in this?
Yeah.
We're living in an age of super bugs.

And with the rates of mutations that we're talking about it's equally probable that they're going toward a less pathogenic form and I think hunger is a factor that pushes it more in the less pathogenic direction.
Yeah.
Hunger is definitely a factor, Monica.
Yes.
I agree.
And that's - the part of what was always been taught is not to waste food, starving children around the world.
So if we're hungry and we know other people are hungry, we're going to go for that.
Hmm.
Thanks very much for the call, Saul(ph).
You're very welcome.
So long.
And let's see if we can go to - this is Brenda(ph).
Brenda from St. Louis.
Hi, Neal.
Hi.
Just last Thursday, my husband and my mother-in-law and sister-in-law we were at a buffet, and he loves seafood, really.
And we were eating crab legs when one of them flipped under the floor.
And he reached them quoting the five-second rule.
And his mother looked at him in horror and said, what are you doing?
And he said, you know, five-second rule.
So he ate it anyway.
And this is off the buffet floor.
Then, when I was a little kid, I didn't know anything about the five-second rule.
If we dropped something on the ground, you just pick it up, brush off all the dirt, and kiss it up to God, and then ate it.
Yeah.
You figured God blessed it, and that was about it on the rule that you have to eat a peck of dirt before you die.
I was going to say it, Brenda, you and I and I maybe a little older than Monica.
Did you grow up with that stipulation that before you die you're going to eat a peck of dirt, whatever a peck is?
You know, I don't think that I did.
But I think that it's something that kids still talk about now.
When I first approached all of these children about the article, the first thing they said is, God made dirt and dirt don't hurt.
And that's how they knew it was okay to eat.
Brenda, thanks very much, and good eating.
Thanks.
(Unintelligible).
Bye-bye.

And finally, the last person you talked to in your article, or the last person you quoted in your article, may have pushed the limits of this further than - all right, Skittles are impervious, M&Ms, Mike and Ikes, he found on the floor of the movie theater where he worked.
He did.
Mike and Ikes are gelatinous and they're not Skittles and they're not M&Ms, but he figured that he was hungry.
They looked pretty good.
And hey, as he said, he'd never got sick.
Monica Hesse, a Washington Post staff writer, author of the recent article, ""That Dropped Doughnut: How Soon and How Often will it Come Back Up?"" with us here in Studio 3A.
Thanks so much for your time today.
Thank you.

In Washington, I'm Neal Conan, NPR News.
To Cape Canaveral, Florida, now where NASA is preparing for the launch of the space shuttle Discovery later today, the first launch since the Columbia disaster two and a half years ago.
Watching the action is Pat Duggins, news director of NPR member station WMFE in Orlando.
You hear him reporting about these launches all the time.
Pat, are they indeed going to go?
Well, at this point, I'm kind of keeping an open mind, Alex.
See, this is my 86th shuttle launch, and I've been to launches where there's a 90 percent chance of good weather and they scrub.
And I've been there when they have a 90 percent chance of bad weather and they go.
So until the solid rocket boosters light, we may have a launch today or we may not.
We'll just have to wait and see.
The weather?
Maybe a 40 percent chance of thunderstorms.
So those storms might come in this afternoon, and if they do, well, they're not going to go.

Well, no, they won't 'cause the problem is if you've got thunderstorms or anvil clouds within 20 miles of the launchpad, if the shuttle were to lift off and then, for example, they lose main engine power within a couple of minutes, astronaut Eileen Collins has to have clear skies in order to do what's known as an RTLS--it's one of those NASA acronyms; it's return to launch site--where basically she does a pitch-around and lands back at the Kennedy Space Center.
It's very dangerous.
It's never been done.
So if they have to do it, they want clear skies for that.
She's the pilot.
She's the pilot.

Yeah, she was NASA's first female shuttle pilot, flew the first mission to rendezvous with the Space Station Mir and she also was the first female commander on a mission that very nearly had to make an emergency landing because, like, five seconds after liftoff, the shuttle she was aboard developed a short circuit, lost two main engine computers, had a hydrogen leak.
I mean, any other problems and she'd have been coming back in a hurry.
This is a very important journey for NASA, isn't it?
Well, it is indeed.
NASA's chief administrator, Michael Griffin, basically said this mission has to go perfectly.
If there's a problem, it could very easily spell the end of the US manned space program.
What about this window cover that fell off?
I heard a report on ""Morning Edition."" It fell off.
It hit some part of the thermal shield and then slipped away.
NASA officials say this is not a big deal at all.
What is it?
Well, what happened was--OK, you've got windows that are the front windshield where the astronauts sit and they look out front so they can see where they're going...
Yeah.
...and then you've got overhead windows.
Now the cover over one of the overhead windows--see, the shuttle is pointed upright.
So the overhead windows point out toward where we are at the press site.
Now there are covers over them and this was maybe, like, two pounds of plastic with foam around it and it's taped in place.
No one saw it fall off.

They were just simply walking around the bottom of the shuttle and they see this cover laying there and they say, `Well, that's not certainly supposed to happen,' and then they start looking around the tail fin where they find two cracked heat shields.

Now these are the shields that protect the shuttle from the 3,000 degrees of heat during re-entry and not too coincidentally that's a cracked heat shield that caused the space shuttle Columbia disaster back in 2003.
So it was a quick repair but a major concern for NASA.
